div.head: THE BABY IN THE CAR.
div.p: There is nothing in nature more curious than the gravity of a little baby. That self-poised, dignified, thoughtful calmness, which you may try in vain to outstare, or disturb. So I thought the other day, as I sat in the cars, looking, as if for a wager, into a pair of baby eyes, that were scrutenizing me with infantile persistence and imperturbability. I might have looked forever. No calling up a blush on that pearl-white skin; no flinching in that calm, quiet eye; limpid as a lake, serene as a seraph.
Of what was the baby thinking?

Not, I am sure, of the delicate lace which fell like a gauzy cloud about its sweet face; nor of its French, embroidered cap, lined with the softest silk; nor of its dainty cloak, tied by mamma's own soft, white fingers, and redolent of the delicate perfume of her hankerchiefs and laces. Not of all this was the petted baby thinking; nor yet of the smart nursery-maid, who drew it fearfully away from the little Irish baby on the knee of her stout neighbor, as if the breath from out its saucy little Hibernian nose were contamination, and its calico frock, and cotton hood, and faded cloak, were the livery of shame as well as poverty. No; else had not those baby features worn that calm majesty, which leaves us with infancy, and only meets us again at the tomb, and which the most sin-scarred creature who ever defaced God's image quails before, as if God himself were looking into his secret soul.

August babyhod! Majestic yet helpless! Imploring yet awing us! Who shall say what wild thoughts of sin thy voiceless eloquence has calmed down to repentant tears! Who shall number the souls washed white by the unconscious touch of thy sinless hand, or make mention of the swift-winged prayers breathed over thee: or tell of the mortal throes with which she who gave thee birth watches thy little lamp of life fade out in utter darkness! And who but the angels see the cords, invisible to human eyes, with which from the spirit land thou drawest after thee the mother, who for her falling tears can scarce trace thy tiny footsteps, and yet, groping and stumbling, follows the good shepherd, who looks lovingly back, as he hides her lamb in his bosom.
